title: The one thing that no one talks about but its probably one of the most toxic type of people.
body:
Sore Winner's, you know who i'm talking about.

People that when they beat you they constantly brag during end game screen, or in game for that matter. People that keep insulting you even after the games already lost, whenever you talk back to them all they say is "YOUR SALTY, SALTY, SALTY, SALTY!!!! HAHAHAHAHA! LUL! XD" or something.

These people are the most obnoxious people to deal with, and 90% of the time their only goal is to piss you off so that if they lose they can report you. Even though they were the one who instigated it and if they had won would, they 100% would have been bragging to their friends at grade school.

replies.body: The best way to deal with those kinds of people is to not respond to them. They are fishing for people to feed into their negativity. So mute them, and treat them like spoiled bratty children: even though you want to hit them, the best way to hurt them is to make them feel like insignificant pieces of shit.
I am so glad you're such a good person who knows who the real pieces of shit are, so you can rid summoners rift of these undesirables. Good hunting man.
I know. I am a good person :-)

as an aside, i personally hate it when someone on either team who is steamrolling flashes their mastery after doing something like killing someone under their tower who's having a bad game

it just feels mean-spirited, and i tend to report it if they do it more than like 3 times in a game

EDIT: 2 clarify, i dont have a problem with the mastery emote's general use when it's not being used for excessive BM. i, for example, love using it when i die,  or using it when pentakills happen.

well its not about it being done to me. i don't really like to see anyone do it, my team or not. i feel like you twisted my words
i dont mind other people doing it on their pentakills either. it's really a case-by-case basis, i didnt mean for it to come across as me policing use of the mastery emote

like say a jungler camps a top laner, and flashes their mastery every time they kill them. by the third time, it starts to seem mean-spirited.

I flash a mastery emote if I pull something off that is skill based and challenging (bait a morg q while I'm under my tower, flash-q over it for the knockup, and then w her under my tower so my retreating 1 hp ezreal can land his q at max range at the last second for the kill). If I merely get a good combo that leads to a successful team fight, I'm not flashing the mastery. That's just playing the game. I've gotta do something impressive before i become a loud-mouth braggart. :D

That being said, if I do something spectacularly STUPID i will also flash mastery (or some other emote) to show my heartfelt shame. Fail to flash over a wall and die? Smite baron 50hp too early? Accidentally flash INTO a nunu ult? Yeah, I'm emoting with pengu. :\

for those wondering

Be Resolute, not Indignant
"It is easier to find men who will volunteer to die, than to find those who are willing to endure pain with patience." -Julius Caesar

Intrinsic to the idea of competition is the notion that, when our pride is on the line, emotions tend to run high. Every person that we encounter is going to carry a different set of circumstances with them into the game, and therefore is going to have a different level of tolerance for frustration. If you end up in a game with an abusive player, don't lower yourself to their level. Instead, politely ask them to calm down.And remember, even if you're having a bad game, quitting or going AFK just ruins the game for the rest of the players. If someone's really starting to bother you, the mute and ignore commands are always there to resolve the situation.

And remember, while nobody likes being insulted, it pays to take a moment to consider the circumstances. Remember that this is a competitive game, and, more often than not, the other player is just venting their frustration. Try not to take it personally. Everyone has a breaking point and everyone rages sometimes. At some point you may find yourself in the other person's shoes.

Almost all of the greatest athletes in their respective competitions were like this. Jordan, Kobe, Conor, Ali, Tyson, Reggie Miller, Lance Armstrong, and the list goes on and on and on and on.

Grow a pair and let it motivate you to get better. Or you can whine about it and stay mediocre for the rest of your life.
And there are countless other athletes that exhibit sportsmanlike behavior, but I think the unsportsmanlike behavior just tends to stand out in history.
